mods.abstract: Douglas talks extensively about his creative process and concepts, including his cartoon characters, his caricature business, his ideas for children's books and toys, and plans for films and TV shows. He recalls weather and sports-related artwork he completed for New Orleans broadcasters Hap Glaudi and Bob Breck. Inspired by his father's example of turning ideas into money, Douglas is a powerhouse of plans. He compares public schools in New Orleans and Baton Rouge and details his approaches to teaching art to youth. He discusses artists in the South Baton Rouge community, his experiences as an artist there, and his concern over young people's declining appreciation of art and music.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.1596. A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Barbara Faulkner.

Keith "Cartoonman" Douglas was born in 1952 in Natchez, Miss. He grew up in New Orleans, attended elementary and high school there, and was interested in art from an early age. He attended Xavier University in New Orleans where he studied under printmaker John Scott. After graduating, he taught art in public schools in New Orleans (Alfred C. Priestly High School) and Baton Rouge (McKinley High School and Southeast Middle School) for many years. He is a successful artist known for his cartoons and caricatures.

physicalDescription.extent: 1 sound cassette (1 hour, 28 minutes); Transcript (41 leaves)
